metadata.title: NIST SP 800-207 to NIST 800-53 Rev 5 Crosswalk
metadata.description: Bidirectional crosswalk mapping ZTA requirements to NIST 800-53 Rev 5 controls. Enables implement-once-satisfy-many for Zero Trust compliance. Implementing a NIST 800-53 control auto-satisfies all ZTA requirements that map to it via the crosswalk engine dual-hub model (ADR D111).

mappings.notes: ZTA architecture planning maps to system development lifecycle (SA-3), security engineering principles (SA-8), and security concept of operations (PL-7). These controls establish the formal ZTA architectural foundation.

mappings.source_title: ZTA Access Control and Policy Enforcement
mappings.notes: ZTA access control policy enforcement maps to access enforcement (AC-3) for logical access and physical access control (PE-3) for physical enforcement. Together these controls enforce ZTA policy decisions at all access points.

ZTA continuous monitoring requirements map to risk assessment (RA-3) for threat context and continuous monitoring (CA-7) for ongoing control effectiveness evaluation. CA-7 is the primary control supporting the ZTA continuous verification posture.

ZTA least privilege architecture maps to least privilege (AC-6) as the primary principle and access enforcement (AC-3) as the enforcement mechanism. AC-6 ensures subjects receive only the permissions necessary for their authorized tasks.

ZTA identity management maps to account management (AC-2) for lifecycle governance, identification and authentication (IA-2) for user identity verification, and authenticator management (IA-5) for credential lifecycle. These three controls collectively satisfy the ZTA identity pillar foundation.

ZTA MFA requirement maps to MFA for privileged accounts (IA-2(1)) and MFA for non-privileged accounts (IA-2(2)). Both enhancements are required to satisfy ZTA's universal MFA mandate — no single-factor authentication is permitted in a ZTA model.

ZTA privileged account management maps to automated audit actions on accounts (AC-2(4)) and role-based account management schemes (AC-2(7)). These enhancements enforce ZTA's requirement for automated oversight and role-scoped privilege assignment.

ZTA privileged access minimization maps to privileged accounts (AC-6(5)) for scoping privilege to the minimum necessary and auditing of privileged function use (AC-6(9)) for accountability. Together these satisfy ZTA's just-in-time and just-enough-access requirements.

ZTA device inventory maps to system component inventory (CM-8) for maintaining a comprehensive device registry and automated inventory updates (CM-8(1)) for continuous inventory accuracy. ZTA requires every device to be known and catalogued before it can be granted access.

ZTA device authentication maps to device identification and authentication (IA-3) for cryptographic device identity and acquisition/development/use of approved functions (SA-4(9)) for ensuring only approved device types can authenticate. IA-3 is the primary control for ZTA device trust establishment.

ZTA device health maps to host-based protection (SC-7(12)) for endpoint security posture enforcement and malicious code protection (SI-3) for integrity verification. ZTA policy engines consume device health signals from these controls to make dynamic access decisions.

ZTA network access control maps to access enforcement (AC-3) for policy-driven access decisions, boundary protection (SC-7) for network perimeter controls, and deny-by-default (SC-7(5)) which is the fundamental ZTA network principle — all traffic is denied unless explicitly permitted by policy.

ZTA data-in-transit protection maps to transmission confidentiality and integrity (SC-8), cryptographic protection (SC-13) for approved algorithm enforcement, and protection of information at rest (SC-28). ZTA mandates encryption of all communications regardless of network location.

ZTA micro-segmentation maps to mandatory access control (AC-3(3)) for fine-grained access enforcement and deny-by-default (SC-7(5)) for default-deny network posture between segments. Micro-segmentation is the network implementation of ZTA's assume-breach principle.

ZTA network traffic analysis maps to system monitoring (SI-4) for real-time traffic inspection and information flow enforcement (AC-4) for policy-based traffic filtering. These controls provide the visibility required for ZTA's continuous trust evaluation of network flows.

ZTA secure application development maps to developer testing (SA-11) for verification, development process/standards (SA-15) for secure SDLC requirements, and software/firmware/information integrity (SI-7) for runtime integrity verification. These controls enforce ZTA's requirement that applications themselves are verified trustworthy.

ZTA application least functionality maps to least functionality (CM-7) for disabling unnecessary functions and process isolation (SC-39) for workload isolation. Minimizing the attack surface of each application is a core ZTA workload security principle.

ZTA application authentication maps to service identification and authentication (IA-9) for authenticating services/APIs to one another and session authenticity (SC-23) for protecting established sessions. ZTA requires mutual authentication between all workloads — no implicit trust between services.

ZTA application supply chain security maps to supply chain protection (SA-12) for acquisition risk management and supply chain controls (SR-3) for component provenance verification. ZTA workloads must include verified software supply chain integrity — malicious components undermine device and application trust.

ZTA data classification maps to security attributes (AC-16) for applying and enforcing data labels, media access (MP-4) for controlling access to labeled data stores, and protection of information at rest (SC-28) for encrypted storage of classified data. ZTA policy engines require classification labels to make access decisions.

ZTA data encryption maps to transmission confidentiality and integrity (SC-8) for data in motion, cryptographic protection (SC-13) for FIPS-validated algorithms, and cryptographic protection of information at rest (SC-28(1)) for data at rest. ZTA mandates encryption as the primary data protection mechanism — the network cannot be trusted.

ZTA data flow enforcement maps to flow control of encrypted information (AC-4(4)) for policy-based encrypted data flow control and network disconnect (SC-7(10)) for terminating unauthorized flows. These controls enforce ZTA data pillar requirements — data must only flow through authorized, policy-compliant paths.

ZTA security monitoring maps to system monitoring (SI-4) for real-time event detection, event logging (AU-2) for identifying auditable events, and audit record generation (AU-12) for capturing comprehensive logs. ZTA's assume-breach principle requires pervasive, continuous monitoring across all pillars.

ZTA log analysis maps to audit record review/analysis/reporting (AU-6) for structured log analysis and automated security alerts (SI-4(2)) for real-time correlation. Cross-pillar log correlation is essential for ZTA's ability to detect lateral movement and policy violations.

ZTA behavioral monitoring maps to inbound/outbound communications traffic analysis (SI-4(4)) and system-generated alerts (SI-4(5)) for anomaly detection. ZTA analytics pillar requires user and entity behavior analytics (UEBA) to detect deviations from baseline — satisfied by these SI-4 enhancements.

ZTA automated incident response maps to incident handling (IR-4) for response procedures, automated response to suspicious events (SI-4(7)) for machine-speed reaction, and contingency plan (CP-2) for continuity during incidents. ZTA automation pillar requires response faster than human operators — SI-4(7) enables automated containment.

ZTA security orchestration maps to automated incident handling processes (IR-4(1)) for SOAR integration and software development lifecycle management (SA-3(1)) for automated security toolchain integration. These controls support ZTA's requirement for coordinated, automated security operations across the enterprise.

ZTA dynamic policy enforcement maps to access enforcement (AC-3) for real-time policy decision application and automated security impact analysis for configuration changes (CM-3(2)) for ensuring policy updates take effect immediately. ZTA policies must be dynamic — access decisions re-evaluated on every request.
